info.name: Angle Gauge Wall Mount
info.pitch: Wall mount for the Shinwa Japanese #19 Stainless Steel Protractor 0-180 degrees with Round Head.

info.name: Art Top
info.pitch: Simple melamine table top with reinforced red oak border.

logs.title: Red Oak Lumber
logs.description: 46bf 1/2" Red Oak @ 3.39

logs.title: 2x Vertical Panels
logs.description: Cut boards to length, joint the edges, domino the edges, and glue boards together.

logs.title: 2x Horizontal Panels
logs.description: Cut boards to length, joint the edges, domino the edges, and glue boards together.

logs.title: 2x Roof Panels
logs.description: Cut boards to length, joint the edges, domino the edges, and glue boards together.

logs.title: Finish Test
logs.description: Cut & prep samples, then test 'Natural' & 'Smoke' Part A.

logs.title: Partial Back & Shelf Panels
logs.description: Cut boards to length and joint the edges.

logs.title: Remaining Back & Shelf Panels
logs.description: Domino the edges, and glue boards together.

logs.title: Square up panels
logs.description: Use a jointer plane to flatten one edge per panel, then reference off that edge to cut the ends perpendicular to it.

logs.title: Select and label panels
logs.description: Using the cutlist, map actual panels to assembly parts to optimize utilization and appearance.

logs.title: Final Case Panel Dimensioning
logs.description: Size and sand the case panels + cut all other panels oversized.

logs.title: Begin Marking Case Panel Joinery
logs.description: Using relative dimensions wherever possible, carefully mark Domino reference lines.

logs.title: Finish Marking Case Panel Joinery
logs.description: Using relative dimensions wherever possible, carefully mark Domino reference lines.

logs.title: Cut thin side piece
logs.description: Cut the thin side piece out of a suitable rough piece and do a first sanding pass

logs.title: Cut dominos
logs.description: Finalize domino locations, then cut them all out and dry assemble to confirm fit.

logs.title: Hybrid back panel
logs.description: Using dominos, glue up the back bin panel hardwood edge to the MDF piece.

logs.title: Hybrid panel flushing
logs.description: Plane down the hardwood part of the hybrid panel so it sits flush with the MDF.

logs.title: Shelf flattening
logs.description: Use a handplane to flatten the four shelves, then sand to 120.

logs.title: Shelf Domino markings
logs.description: Measuring from the top of the panels, mark the domino reference line 2mm above the final shelf position.

logs.title: Finalize RHS shelf dimensions.
logs.description: Carefully cut down RHS shelf panels to idnetical final dimension.

logs.title: Cut display strips.
logs.description: Rip strips of the right width then make sure they are equal and parallel with a handplane.

logs.title: Cut shelf domino reference stick.
logs.description: Rip a strip and make sure sides are parallel. Mark domino locations at regular intervals across the width

logs.title: Shelf Joinery.
logs.description: Mark and cut shelf dominos on side, middle, and shelf pieces using a story stick.

logs.title: Bin Shelves.
logs.description: Dry assemble case and take final measurements for bin shelf/back sizes then cut shelves to size.

logs.title: Back Panel Sizing
logs.description: Cut back panels to final width using shelves as story sticks.

logs.title: Shelf Domino Marks
logs.description: Create story stick for back panel dominos + mark domino locations on shelves and reference line on vertical panels.

logs.title: Finish Stain Test #2
logs.description: Sand and apply 'Citrine', 'Pine', and 'Touch of Gold' finish samples to test pieces.

logs.title: Shelf Back Dominos
logs.description: Using a story stick, mark then cut the domino mortises in the back of all the shelves and the MDF panels.

logs.title: Finish Testing
logs.description: Sand down a sample board and test different combinations of finishes and paints.

logs.title: Book Shelves Joinery
logs.description: Measure and cut domino mortises for the book shelf parts & their connecting pieces.

logs.title: Back Panel Joinery
logs.description: Mark out domino locations and cut mortises in display back, middle, and LHS support.

logs.title: Test Fit
logs.description: Cut out remaining dominos and do a dry assembly of the parts, adjusting dominos as needed

logs.title: Final Touches
logs.description: Cut out first shelf notch & cut domino mortises. Measure and cut out bar holes. Cut missing/incorrect domino mortises from dry fit.

logs.title: Domino Tenon Glueing
logs.description: Glue the domino tenons into all the tight mortises.

logs.title: Shelf Glue up + Finishing prep
logs.description: Glue the two shelf components together for both shelves. Start final sanding and adding tape to glue surfaces before paint.

logs.title: Finishing Prep
logs.description: Sand the glued shelf pieces flush. Continue sanding and taping over joinery for painted parts.

logs.title: Roof Parts
logs.description: Cut roof pieces to correct width then sand to 120 grit. Cut 45deg angle on top piece and use hand plane to get it down to 35deg. Using top dimension, cut MDF back triangle.

logs.title: Roof Miter
logs.description: Dial in the angle, then cut the roof miter to 35deg. Make sure to save the triangular off-cuts for the attic corners.

logs.title: Roof Joinery
logs.description: Cut Domino mortises in roof miter, attic back piece, roof pieces, and top shelf. Glue dominos in back piece.

logs.title: Prep Top & Bottom
logs.description: Sand top and bottom pieces to 120 grit then add masking tape to joinery.

logs.title: Roof Sizing
logs.description: Cut straight end of the roof to the correct dimension using the back as reference.

logs.title: Roof Finishing
logs.description: Round external roof corners and add light roundover on the lip. Sand smooth and tape miter.

logs.title: Oil Parts
logs.description: Prepare oil finish and apply to all pieces that won't be painted.

logs.title: Paint
logs.description: Prepare paint, clean dust of parts and paint first coat. Lightly (220 grit) sand first coat, remove dust and apply second coat.

logs.title: Oil Fail
logs.description: Test oil on sample piece, then on painted parts. Sand off oil from painted parts.

logs.title: Paint 3rd coat
logs.description: Prepare more paint, then apply a 3rd coat. Carefully tip the brush and follow the direction of the grain to give each piece an even finish.

logs.title: Paint Scuff
logs.description: Brush the panels to remove dirt, then using a piece of cardboard gently smooth all the pieces to an even & smooth surface.

logs.title: Paint Oil
logs.description: Sand the unpainted surfaces of the painted panels to remove stray paint. Add Rubio to all painted surfaces

logs.title: Installation bits & bobs
logs.description: Furniture straps + flexible shims + felt strips

logs.title: Paint Oil Second Coat
logs.description: Add 2nd coat of Rubio to all painted surfaces

logs.title: Wax
logs.description: Wipe on the wax with a non-abrasive white pad, then buff it off with a paper towel.

logs.title: Glue Prep
logs.description: Start removing the tape from the panels + sanding the paint/finish off the dominos and edges.

logs.title: More Glue Prep
logs.description: Continue removing the tape from the panels + sanding the paint/finish off the dominos and edges.

logs.title: Final Glue Prep + Glue
logs.description: Finish removing the tape from the panels + sanding the paint/finish off the dominos and edges. Glue the first shelf into the back

logs.title: Final Assembly
logs.description: Every 4-8h, glue panels together joint-by-joint using minimal glue and making sure everything is square and flush.

logs.title: Final Assembly
logs.description: Every 4-8h, glue panels together joint-by-joint using minimal glue and making sure everything is square and flush.

logs.title: Final Assembly
logs.description: Every 4-8h, glue panels together joint-by-joint using minimal glue and making sure everything is square and flush.

logs.title: Final Assembly
logs.description: Every 4-8h, glue panels together joint-by-joint using minimal glue and making sure everything is square and flush.

logs.title: Final Assembly
logs.description: Every 4-8h, glue panels together joint-by-joint using minimal glue and making sure everything is square and flush.

logs.title: Final Assembly
logs.description: Every 4-8h, glue panels together joint-by-joint using minimal glue and making sure everything is square and flush.

logs.title: Caulk Testing
logs.description: Experiment with adding white caulk to the joints that aren't quite flush.

logs.title: Final Assembly
logs.description: Every 4-8h, glue panels together joint-by-joint using minimal glue and making sure everything is square and flush.

logs.title: Final Assembly
logs.description: Attach RHS panel to shelves.

logs.title: Final Assembly
logs.description: Cut and attach strips of felt to base, keeping the reveal consistent and roughly 1/4".

logs.title: Final Assembly
logs.description: Attach top shelf to full shelf assembly.

logs.title: Final Assembly
logs.description: Attach roof parts to each other

logs.title: Paint patching
logs.description: Mix up and apply 3x coats of milk paint to shelf mistake.

logs.title: Final Assembly
logs.description: Attach roof back to roof pieces after trimming the dominos to fit diagonally.

logs.title: Final Assembly
logs.description: Attach roof assembly to shelf assembly. Use glue and a syringe to make sure there is a consistent bond.

logs.title: Trim
logs.description: Cut down long 45deg piece of trim to glue to the back of the roof to hide the gap.

logs.title: Trim Finishing
logs.description: Add rubio oil to trim parts and to shelf mistake touch-ups.

logs.title: Trim Assembly
logs.description: Cut down side trim to length and glue in place.

logs.title: Trim Assembly
logs.description: Cut down back trim to length and glue + nail in place.

logs.title: Paint retouch
logs.description: Sand off failed paint touch-up and re-paint. Use original large brush and long strokes.

logs.title: Paint retouch
logs.description: Add final coat of paint, then smooth it out with brown paper once dry.

logs.title: Oil retouch
logs.description: Add small amount of rubio to retouched area, making sure to cover everything that was sanded.

logs.title: Wax retouch + brown caulk
logs.description: Rub furniture wax on retouched area. Then use brown caulk in a syringe to fill obvious gaps.

logs.title: Delivery
logs.description: Pack shelf in moving blanket, then deliver.

info.name: Block Plane Mount
info.pitch: Magnetic wall mount for the Lie-Nielsen No. 60-1/2 Adjustable Mouth Block Plane.

info.name: Board Hook

steps.title: Doors
body: Clamp a piece of template material to the face frame so that it covers the opening of both cabinet doors. From the back of the cabinet frame, trace the shape of the face frame opening onto the template material. Marking multiple times ensures a more accurate template and reduces the chance of the pencil's thickness offsetting the line. Label the template side that is being marked with "INSIDE". Using a saw follow the outside of the line, cutting out the template as precisely as possible. Refine the shape to a more precise match with some sanding.

Select a piece of veneered plywood that is larger than the pattern and whose grain should be visible in the finished piece. Mark the selected area as "OUTSIDE". Temporarily place the pattern onto the veneered plywood making sure that the "INSIDE" face of the template is facing the "OUTSIDE" face of the panel. Trace the pattern onto the plywood, then cut it out roughly with a saw. Use double-stick tape to solidly reattach the template to the veneered plywood panel. Using a 1/8" rabbeting router bit, run the bit's bearing against the template without cutting into the template. Detach the template then use a flush trim router bit to remove the remaining material. Verify the fit of the panel in the frame and adjust with sanding as needed for an even reveal all around.

Mark the center of the panel, then mark a line perpendicular from the bottom which intersects with that center mark. Using a saw, make a cut centered on that line. The most common saw kerfs will remove roughly the right amount of material from both panels to maintain the 1/8" reveal between the panels, but if you used a different size of rabbeting bit or have a smaller kerf width, cut the appropriate amount off both sides. First apply edge banding to the fresh vertical cut, then to the continuous top-side-bottom face.
Apply finish, then measure and cut for hardware as specified by the manufacturer. Take care in ensuring the orientation of the panel is as intended and consistent with the now-erased "OUTSIDE" mark.

steps.title: Panels
body: Use the bending jig from earlier to trace out a half circle onto the 1/4" material. Use a jigsaw and some sanding blocks to cut out the half-circle 1/4" _outside_ the line and adjust the fit in the bookshelf rabbet. Once acceptable, mark where the half-circle lands in the middle of the thickness of the first shelf and cut that line with a saw

Measure the panel width from rabbet to rabbet and cross cut the remaining 1/4" panels to that width. With the bookshelf facing down, place the previously cut half-circle where it will be attached and measure from its bottom edge to the middle of the next shelf. Subtract 1mm and rip the a panel to that dimension. Place on the bookshelf and repeat for all shelves.

Mark the back of the panels and their orientation. Remove the panels, flip them over and apply the selected wallpaper. Depending on the width of the wallpaper it can take up to 4500mm of material to cover all the panels, less if the cabinet panel is excluded or the wallpaper is wide enough to be used for more than one panel. Place the panels back on the back of the bookshelf and use a pin nailer or stapler to semi-permanently attach it to the frame.

info.pitch: Clamping cauls used to keep glue-ups flat when clamps can't reach.

info.name: Centrotec Mount
info.pitch: Compact wall mount for cenrotec bits and 1/4" router bits.

info.name: Chisel Mount

info.name: Clamp Rack
info.pitch: Clamp rack for Bessey EHK and KRE clamps.

info.name: Clamping Square
info.pitch: 90Â° clamping aides for Bessey TK-6 clamps.

body: This clamping square was created as a lower cost alternative to the [Woodpeckers clamping squares + CSP clamps](https://www.woodpeck.com/clamping-squares-plus.html) and their multiple clones. The design comes with some tradeoffs:
- Can only be used/clamped on the inside of a joint and therefore cannot be used to line up butt joints.
- Both the square and the clamps are bulkier and harder to manipulate.
- Lower precision. Initially it is entirely dependent on the squareness of cut, but wood is more likely to change over time than aluminum.
- Squeeze-out may bond to the surface of the square if some countermeasures are not added (like packing tape).
_Makes two squares_
materials: Scrap material about 3/4" thick and enough for a >192mm square.

steps.title: Cut a Square
body: Cut a square with roughly 192mm sides as precisely as possible

steps.title: Split The Square
body: Pick two opposing corners and connect with a line.

steps.title: Notch The Square
body: Cut off the same two opposing corners 23mm deep and perpendicular to th line.

steps.title: Cut The Square
body: Cut the along the line centering it on the kerf.

steps.title: Mark The Holes
body: Mark a line parallel to each face 16mm from the face. Then, measure and mark each hole position every 32mm referencing the faces.

steps.title: Drill & Chamfer
body: Drill and chamfer 3/8" holes as perpendicular as possible. Also sand the corner between the two reference faces for glue clearance.

steps.title: (optional) Packing Tape
body: Add some clear plastic packing tape to the reference surfaces to avoid gluing the square to your work.

logs.title: S2S Lumber
logs.description: 4/4 and 6/4 Clear Walnut

logs.title: Bench Seat Glue-up
logs.description: Select pleasing arrangement of 6/4 boards that will produce a 4x1' panel. Joint edges, add alignment aids, and glue together.

logs.title: Template Cutting
logs.description: Cut out templates from 1/2" MDF.

logs.title: Template Copying
logs.description: Use the quadrant templates to duplicate them three more times on more 1/2" MDF. Remember to use a center punch to mark the leg holes in the seat quadrants.

logs.title: Template Assembly
logs.description: Glue the quadrants together into a template for the seat and another for the shelf. It may be helpful to use alignment aids.

logs.title: Shelf Glue-up
logs.description: Select pleasing arrangement of boards for the shelf ensuring that the sections that will join to the legs are straight grain. Rip, joint, add alignment aids, and glue the boards together into a panel.

logs.title: Shelf Joint Fix
logs.description: Re-cut the mating sufaces of the final shelf glue-up and assemble like before.

logs.title: Template Routing
logs.description: Use templates to mark the rough stock/panels and cut the pieces out with a jigsaw. Stick the templates to the pieces and use a bearing-guided router bit to duplicate the templates.

logs.title: Leg Fixes
logs.description: Use a handplane to flatten areas that broke from the leg pieces during template routing and glue a similar color/grain piece from the off-cut pile.

logs.title: Panel Flattening
logs.description: Use 40grit and an aggressive sander to flatten the seat and shelf panel seams. Follow-up with 120grit until previous scratches are removed.

logs.title: Leg Fixes 2
logs.description: Cut off as much of the extra leg fixes as possible using a coping saw. Re-attach the template and route those sections again in multiple passes.

logs.title: Rough Seat Rounding
logs.description: Use as large of a radius router bit as possible to fillet the top of the bench. Using an aggressive sander and 40grit, make the curve even larger, then blend the curve into the top over a long wide area.

logs.title: Leg Chatter Fix
logs.description: Use tape as a dam and add a generous amount of wood filler to fill any router chatter in the legs. Once dry, use a rasp to smooth the radius.

logs.title: Leg & Shelf Rounding
logs.description: Use a roundover bit with half the thickness of the stock to route all the edges of the leg and shelf pieces. Avoid joint surfaces.

logs.title: Baltic Birch Sheets
logs.description: 4x 18mm 5x5' Baltic Birch @ 135.57

logs.title: Whitewash Test
logs.description: Test 'Nordic White' Precolor + 'Super White' Part A on scraps.

logs.title: Bending Jig
logs.description: Cut out two matching template pieces out of 3/4" MDF. Includes alignment slots.

logs.title: Bending Jig Assembly
logs.description: Cut alignment blocks and attach to templates.

logs.title: Frame Piece Breakdown
logs.description: Rough breakdown of 4x frame pieces along the grain to allow kerf bending.

logs.title: Panel Breakdown
logs.description: Rough breakdown + labelling of of remaining panels into pieces that can be further sized on the "MFT" table.

logs.title: Finalize Width of Frames
logs.description: Cut frame pieces to final width of 415mm + parallel sides.

logs.title: Finalize Frames
logs.description: Square up one remaining side of frames then cut to 798mm.

logs.title: Kerf Bending Test
logs.description: Test kerf bending parameters on off cuts from frames.

logs.title: Frame Kerf Cuts
logs.description: Mark, set up, and cut all the kerfs in 4x frame pieces.

logs.title: Bending Jig Details
logs.description: Add clear tape to bending jig edges & attach clamping and alignment blocks

logs.title: Frame Bending 1
logs.description: Wet the outside of the kerf bend & add glue using a syringe. Bend frame over jig and attach with clamps. Leave to cure for >24h.

logs.title: Frame Bending 2
logs.description: Wet the outside of the kerf bend & add glue using a syringe. Bend frame over jig and attach with clamps. Leave to cure for >24h.

logs.title: Frame Bending 3
logs.description: Wet the outside of the kerf bend & add glue using a syringe. Bend frame over jig and attach with clamps. Leave to cure for >24h.

logs.title: Frame Bending 2
logs.description: Wet the outside of the kerf bend & add glue using a syringe. Bend frame over jig and attach with clamps. Leave to cure for >24h.

logs.title: Inside Kerf Bend Sanding
logs.description: Using a flap wheel, sand the inside of the kerf bends to remove all the excess glue and smooth out the surface on all frames.

logs.title: Final Dimensioning of Frames
logs.description: Placing the frame pieces against a reference surface (wall, bench), mark the correct measurements and trim with a track saw.

logs.title: Frame Joinery
logs.description: Cut Domino (6x40mm) mortises in the short ends of the frames to connect each pairs together.

logs.title: Frame Joinery 2
logs.description: Cut Domino connector mortises in the short ends of the frames to connect each pairs together.

logs.title: Frame Assembly
logs.description: Insert all dominos and connector hardware, add glue, assemble, and tighten connectors.

logs.title: Final Dimensioning of Sides & Tops
logs.description: Using the final measurements from the frames, cut all side and top pieces to that width.

logs.title: Final Dimensioning of Sides
logs.description: Sneak up on the correct dimension to cut the sides to the correct height so the frames are parallel on either side.

logs.title: Final Dimensioning of Frames & Tops
logs.description: Using a tall stop block cut the frames to the same final width on top and bottom. Use that same setup to cut the tops to width.

logs.title: Rubio Monocoat
logs.description: Super White - 350ml

logs.title: Formica Laminate
logs.description: 2x 4x8' Mission White @ 68.80

logs.title: Piece selection
logs.description: Compare all tops and sides and keep the most consistent ones. Enough for one less middle module.

logs.title: Module assembly
logs.description: Using glue, pin nails, and screws: assemble the three modules. Plane down any lips at the joints.

logs.title: Module rabbet
logs.description: Using a rabbeting bit at a router table, cut a 1/4" rabbet along the back of all the modules.

logs.title: Module inside sanding
logs.description: Sand the inside of each module to 120 grit. Then take internal measurements for the back panels.

logs.title: Backs
logs.description: Cut back panels to size and start rounding the corners. Refine the radius with a sander for an exact fit.

logs.title: Backs
logs.description: Finish rounding large end radius and hand-fit each back with a sander and handplane.

logs.title: Backs
logs.description: Finish rounding last back.

logs.title: Edge Banding Strips
logs.description: Cut 10mm strips of 4/4 material enough to cover all the case edges. Also cut the same thickness of 8/4 material to edge band the corners.

logs.title: Case Edge Banding
logs.description: Cut edge banding material to length and apply to shelves and one of the end cases.

logs.title: Case Edge Banding
logs.description: Cut edge banding material to length and apply to the second end case.

logs.title: Trim Edge Banding
logs.description: Use a handplane to smooth the transitions between the edge banding pieces on the face. Then use a flush trim router bit to remove the excess edge banding.

logs.title: Final Trim of Edge Banding
logs.description: Chisel out corners of edge banding and sand the inside and outside transitions.

logs.title: Edge Banding Touchup & Shelves
logs.description: Flush up and route extra material on edge banding touchup. Using a router with an offset base, trim the shelf edge banding flush. Re-apply edge banding if mistakes are made.

logs.title: Edge Banding Touchup & Sanding
logs.description: Finish flushing up the redone shelf's edge banding, then sand all the shelves and backs.

logs.title: Mounting Bolts
logs.description: Align the sections at the top/back corner and along the whole top seam, then drill four holes through both case parts. Once each joint. Flush up visible transitions with a sander and handplane while bolted together.

logs.title: Bolt Recesses + Cable pattern
logs.description: Using a 3/4" forstner bit, add a recessed pocket for each bolt head. Re-assemble the console with final hardware to check and adjust the fitment. Sand all the face frame faces to 120grit. Cut out a pattern for the cable management punch-outs in the backs.

logs.title: Attach Back Panels
logs.description: Using a small bead of glue to avoid squeeze out on the interior, assemble the back panels to the cases. Use a nailer to immobilize the panels while applying pressure twoards the inside of the box. Go back around the gap with more glue to fill any gaps.

logs.title: Case Touch-Ups
logs.description: Use a chisel or chisel plane to remove excess glue from the backs and sand the surface flush. Use wood filler to fill the screw holes on th top and bottom of the cases. Sand flush while assembled and break the sections apart.

logs.title: Case Laminate Breakdown
logs.description: Unroll a 4x8' laminate sheet and cut out all the case parts.

logs.title: Base Parts
logs.description: Cut out all base parts into correctly sized rectangles.

logs.title: Base Assembly
logs.description: Use a fixturing table setup to assemble one side of the base

logs.title: Base Assembly
logs.description: Use a fixturing table setup to assemble the second side of the base

logs.title: Walnut
logs.description: 9bf 1/2" Natural Walnut @ 269.00 + 2x8' Premium Walnut Veneer @ 79.99 + 2x8' Birch Veneer @ 54.99 + 250' Iron-On Walnut Banding

logs.title: Rough Pictographs
logs.description: Make templates from 1/2" MDF, then roughly mark and cut them out of raw 1/2" Walnut boards.

logs.title: Base Edge Banding
logs.description: Apply and trim edge banding on base components. Select, joint and glue a panel for remaining oversized pictographs.

logs.title: Final Rough Pictographs
logs.description: Mark and cut remainig pictographs.

logs.title: Final Pictographs
logs.description: Stick the templates to a worksurface and the rough shapes to the templates. Using a flush trim router bit, trim the pictograph pieces to a final size.

logs.title: Final Rectangle Pictographs
logs.description: Use a handplane to shape the rectangular pictorgraphs that are too thin to pattern route.

logs.title: Base Plugs
logs.description: Cut, install, and cut 15mm plugs for domino connectors.

logs.title: Case Banding
logs.description: Add walnut edge banding to all the case fronts. Trim on a router table and sand inside edge till smooth.

logs.title: Case Joint Relief
logs.description: Using routers and jigs, dish out one side of the middle case section to ensure the sections attach flush.

logs.title: Case Relief & Cable Passthrough
logs.description: Dish out the other side of the middle case section. Cut out the first cable passthrough hole.

logs.title: Cable Passthrough
logs.description: Cut out the second cable passthrough hole.

logs.title: Base Assembly
logs.description: Glue the sides and middle sections together into a single piece.

logs.title: Veneer Middle Section
logs.description: Cut down 2x 2x8' walnut veneer rolls for case sections. Use contact adhesive to glue veneer sheet to both sides of middle case.

logs.title: Shelf Pin Jig
logs.description: Cut and assemble shelf pin jig.

logs.title: Fan Cutout
logs.description: Cut out rectangle from the top of the middle case section to mount a fan.

logs.title: Middle Shelf
logs.description: Cut down the middle shelf stock to 4mm less than the width and 10mm less than the depth. Then, notch the back to allow fan cables to access the power strip.

logs.title: Contact Adhesive
logs.description: 1 Quart 3M Fastbond Contact Adhesive 30NF @ 51.12

logs.title: Power Strip
logs.description: TROND 24 Outlet Surge Protector Power Strip @ 25.99

logs.title: Power Strip
logs.description: AC Infinity AIRPLATE S5 Cooling Fan System - Dual 80 @ 29.99

logs.title: Veneer Outer Sections
logs.description: Use contact adhesive to glue a single veneer sheet all the way around the two outer sections.

logs.title: Outer Shelves
logs.description: Cut down the outer shelves to 4mm less than the width and 10mm less than the depth.

logs.title: Wood Filler
logs.description: Use matching wood filler to fix any gaps in the veneer.

logs.title: Final Case Sanding
logs.description: Sand all case parts to 120 grit.

logs.title: Outside Finish
logs.description: Add a coat of Rubio Walnut finish to the veneered walnut surfaces of the case parts and base. Stay clear of the birch insides and sand off any accidents as soon as possible. Rub surface with brown paper when cured.

logs.title: Inside Finish
logs.description: Add a coat of Rubio Super White to exposed birch insides of the case and shelves. Rub surface with brown paper when cured.

logs.title: Shelf Pins
logs.description: Mark out shelf pin locations with jig, then drill them out with a 5/16" bit, and install the sleeves.

logs.title: Case Install
logs.description: Place the base on the intended location and adjust feet to flat/level using a level. Place the case pieces upside down on a flat moving blanket and bolt them together flush. Flip the base over and screw it to the cases through the bottom. Flip over the assembled usit and slide into position.

logs.title: Door Sizing
logs.description: Measure door openings and cut down material. Ensure correct partial overlay, gaps, and edge banding thickness are accounted for. Then, round corners of outer doors to 35mm radius.

logs.title: Door Veneer
logs.description: Cut down walnut & birch veneer. Add birch veneer to inside with contact adhesive & trim. Edge band and trim the edges of the doors. Add walnut veneer to outside of doors with contact adhesive & trim.

logs.title: Final Sanding
logs.description: Sand down the doors and pictograph parts.

logs.title: Pictograph Edges
logs.description: Pick the show side of all the pictographs and then break the face and side edges.

logs.title: Outer Door Finishing
logs.description: Add a coat of Walnut Rubio to the edges and fronts of the doors.

logs.title: Pictograph Finishing
logs.description: Add a coat of Walnut Rubio to the top and sides of the pictographs (not underneath).

logs.title: Inner Door Finishing
logs.description: Add a coat of Super White Rubio to the birch inside of the doors.

logs.title: Pictograph Recoat
logs.description: Rub down all finished surfaces of the pictographs with brown paper then lightly apply another coat of Walnut Rubio.

logs.title: Pictograph Install
logs.description: Carefully place the pictographs onto the doors and surround each piece with tape to save its position. Sand underneath each pictograph to remove the finish and then glue them back on one-by-one.

logs.title: Door Install
logs.description: Drill appropriate holes in the doors and boxes, then install the euro hinges (using the printed hinge offsets if necessary). Adjust hinges as necessary.

info.name: Pictograph Console
info.pitch: Low-profile TV console with geometric panels & electronics cabinet.

info.name: Pipi Hut

info.name: Pliers Rail

info.name: Saddle Mount

info.name: Saw Holder

info.name: Scrap Cart

info.name: Screw Clamp

info.name: Screwdriver Holder

info.name: Scrub Plane Mount

info.name: Sharpening Mount

info.name: Shooting Board
info.pitch: Traditional fixed 90deg shooting board with sloped runner.

info.name: Shooting Plane Mount

info.name: Sliding Bevel Mount
info.pitch: Wall mount for the Crucible Sliding Bevel.

info.name: Slot Hatch
info.pitch: User-friendly vector pattern for large pocket cuts with the Shaper Origin.

info.name: Small Chisel Plane Mount
info.pitch: Wall mount for the Lie-Nielsen No. No.97-1/2 Small Chisel Plane.

info.name: Small Combo Square Mount
info.pitch: Wall mount for the Bridge City CS-6v2 combination square.

info.name: Small Spokeshave Mount
info.pitch: Wall mount for the HNT Gordon Small Curved Spokeshave

info.name: Smoothing Plane Wall Mount
info.pitch: Wall mount for the HNT Gordon Smoothing Plane.

info.name: Snuffle Frame
info.pitch: Custom sized frame for rowdy dog's snuffle pad.

info.name: Stanley Smoother Plane Wall Mount

info.name: Starrett Meter Mount
info.pitch: Compact wall mount for an aluminum Starrett imperial/metric meter ruler.

info.name: Stool Stool
info.pitch: Flat-pack squatty potty.

info.name: Suizan Folding Saw Wall Mount.
info.pitch: Bottom support to mount foldable Suizan pull saws onto a wall.

logs.title: Half Circle Mirror
logs.description: 1x 800x400mm Half Circle Mirror @ 110.99

logs.title: Pattern Material
logs.description: 2x 1/2" 2x4' MDF Sheets @ 24.99

logs.title: Templates
logs.description: Cut out 'back', 'mdf', 'segment', and 'shelf' templates from pattern material. The 'mdf' piece can be cut from the inside of the 'back'.

logs.title: Rough Parts
logs.description: Sand hardwood board(s) to 120 grit. Trace templates onto board(s), then cut them out with a jigsaw.

logs.title: Flush Trim Segments
logs.description: Using a router table, flush trim the segments one by one using the template.

logs.title: Template Smoothing
logs.description: Fill any imperfections in the templates using wood filler. Then, with 80 grit sandpaper on a dowel, smooth out the templates to make them smooth to the touch.

logs.title: Segment Mortises & Filler Strips
logs.description: Cut mortises into arch segments biasing away from the outside surface that will be trimmed. Cut down 1 & 2mm strips to glue to the mdf arch back that was cut too small.

logs.title: Arch Assembly
logs.description: Glue together the arch segments using floating tenons and tape as clamps.

logs.title: Arch Back Assembly
logs.description: Glue veneers onto outside of the MDF back to match the arch. Then use a slot cutting bit to make 1/4" biscuit slots in the arch and the MDF back. Glue together using DIY 1/4" loose tenons.

logs.title: Back Assembly
logs.description: Use a slot cutting bit to make 1/4" biscuit slots in the arch and the back. Glue together using DIY 1/4" loose tenons.

logs.title: Outer Flush Trimming
logs.description: Stick the 'back' and 'shelf' templates onto the corresponding pieces and flush trim at the router table. Then, replace the bit with a bowl cutting template bit and follow the inside of the mirror pocket.

logs.title: Pocket Routing
logs.description: Using the same bowl bit in a handheld router, cut out the remaining pockets on the back and the shelf. Use a light final pass and take care to keep the bottoms as flat and uniform as possible.

logs.title: Arch Patch
logs.description: Cut a rectangular section around the gouge in the arch and glue in a tightly fitting replacement chunk from leftover material.

logs.title: Initial Sanding
logs.description: Using sanding sponges, scrapers, and files, bring every surface to a smooth 120 grit.

logs.title: Shelf Joinery
logs.description: Create floating tenon joints all along the shelf-to-back connection. Reference from the top of the shelf and use a straight fence to index on the back.

logs.title: Shelf Assembly
logs.description: Finalize all rough patches with a scraper and sandpaper, then assemble the shelf to the back.

logs.title: Keilverbinder Slots
logs.description: Cut out sets of Keilverbinder slots 16" apart to allow flush wall mounting.

logs.title: Wood Filler
logs.description: Fill all the joinery gaps between the shelf and the back with some walnut colored wood filler.

logs.title: Finishing
logs.description: Sand the entire assembly with 180 grit sanding sponge, then clean off the dust with waxed cheese cloth. Then, apply coat of hardwax finishing oil.

logs.title: Final Finishing
logs.description: Scuff finish with maroon abrasive pad, then apply thin final coat of hardwax finishing oil.

info.name: Sunrise Mirror
info.pitch: Entryway half-moon mirror with small shelf to dump pockets.

info.name: TV Console Mod
info.pitch: Modification to a TV console to prevent sag.

info.name: Tape Dispenser
info.pitch: Simple wall-mounted tape dispenser.

info.name: Tic-Tac Toilet
info.pitch: Playful wall decoration & storage shelving.

info.name: Tool Cabinet
info.pitch: French-cleat-mounted storage cabinet made of scrap material.

info.name: Tool Shelf
info.pitch: French-cleat-mounted storage shelf made of scrap material.

info.name: Topper Block
info.pitch: DIY version of the Wyrmwod Topper Block.

info.name: Trotten Top
info.pitch: Replacement top for the Ikea Trotten standing desk.

info.name: Wax Mount
info.pitch: Wall mounted holder for Lie-Nielsen plane wax.

introduction.body: Designed to work even when the stick is smaller than the holder

info.name: Wedding Band
info.pitch: Custom wedding band model to be sent to a manufacturing company.

info.name: Wood is Good Hook
info.pitch: Wall mount for Wood is Good 18oz mallet.

logs.title: Laminate
logs.description: 4x8" Formica laminate sheet - Mojave, Matte

logs.title: Raw Materials
logs.description: 18, 15, and 12mm baltic birch plywood. 3/4" MDF. 6/4 Walnut

logs.title: Frame Parts
logs.description: Cut frame pieces to length & width from 18mm birch.

logs.title: Frame Joinery
logs.description: Clamp frame panels together and drill counter-sunk screw holes 3x per joint.

logs.title: Frame Assembly
logs.description: Sand each frame part to 180 grit. Add glue to joint surfaces and assemble.

logs.title: Drawer Hardware
logs.description: 6x 18" Blum Movento drawer slide pairs.

logs.title: Drawer Parts (1/3)
logs.description: Carefully lay out, then cut all drawer parts.

logs.title: Drawer Parts (2/3)
logs.description: Carefully lay out, then cut more drawer parts.

logs.title: Drawer Parts (3/3)
logs.description: Carefully lay out, then cut remaining drawer parts.

logs.title: Drawer Parts Sanding
logs.description: Sand all the drawer parts to 180 grit.

logs.title: Drawer Assembly Prototype
logs.description: Prototype process to assemble drawers (with glue and nails) while assembling the first one.

logs.title: Drawer Mounting Prototype
logs.description: Figure out installation procedure for drawer slides and mount the first one.

logs.title: Drawer Assembly
logs.description: Assemble remaining drawers.

logs.title: Lateral Stabilizer Set
logs.description: 2 x Movento Lateral Stabilizer Set

logs.title: Drawer Finishing Prototype
logs.description: Figure out final cleanup & sanding procedure for drawers and do the first one.

logs.title: Glue Cleanup
logs.description: Using a sharp plane blade, remove glue from the inside of the drawer corners.

logs.title: Drawer Sanding
logs.description: Flush out the drawer panel joints with a chisel, then fill in the nail holes with wood filler. Finally, sand all the exposed edges/surfaces to 180 grit.

logs.title: Seat Stock
logs.description: Cut down 8/4 board into seat halves and glue them together.

logs.title: Seat Template
logs.description: Cut a template for the seat with holes to punch the center and each leg's direction.

logs.title: Seat Roughing
logs.description: Place the template on the material and cut as close to the line as possible to remove the bulk of the material. Stick on the template and remove the remaining material using multiple passes with a pattern and flush cut router bit.

logs.title: Leg Roughing
logs.description: Use a jigsaw to cut down 8/4 material into 22" sticks. Make sure to prioritize material with straight grain.

logs.title: Stretcher Roughing
logs.description: Use a jigsaw to cut down 8/4 material into 16" sticks. Make sure to prioritize material with straight grain.

logs.title: Stretcher Sizing
logs.description: Use a scrub plane to cut down the stretchers to a slightly over 1 1/4" square profile.

logs.title: Stretchers Layout
logs.description: Mark the center of the stretcher stock on either end. Use a compass to draw a circle of the intended final radius on either end.

logs.title: Octagonize Stretchers
logs.description: Use a handplane with a rough setting to remove material from the long-side corners of the stretchers until they are octagonal.

logs.title: Taper Octagonal Stretchers
logs.description: Use a handplane with a rough setting to taper all faces of the stretchers until they touch the layout marks on the ends. Front stretcher should be double-tapered.

logs.title: Round Stretchers
logs.description: Use a handplane with a rough setting to round the octagonal corners, then a fine setting to refine the shape to a circular surface with no facets.

logs.title: Sand Stretchers
logs.description: Use soft sanding sponges to smooth the stretcher surface until facets are completely removed.

logs.title: Legs Layout
logs.description: Mark the center of the stretcher stock on either end. Use a compass to draw a circle of the intended final radius on either end.

logs.title: Octagonize Legs
logs.description: Use a handplane with a rough setting to remove material from the long-side corners of the legs until they are octagonal.

logs.title: Taper Octagonal Legs
logs.description: Use a handplane with a rough setting to taper all faces of the legs until they touch the layout marks on the ends. Front stretcher should be double-tapered.

logs.title: Round Legs
logs.description: Use a handplane with a rough setting to round the octagonal corners, then a fine setting to refine the shape to a circular surface with no facets.

logs.title: Sand Legs
logs.description: Use soft sanding sponges to smooth the stretcher surface until facets are completely removed.

logs.title: Milk Paint
logs.description: 16oz Flag Red & 16oz Lily Pad Green @ 11.99

logs.title: Milk Paint
logs.description: 16oz Soft White @ 18.99 & 16oz Low Sheen Finishing Cream @ 32.99

logs.title: Leg Joinery
logs.description: Drill 3x 1" diameter bores leaning 15deg away from the seat centerline. Use a tenon cutter to cut down the small end of the legs to a 1" diameter tenon. Hammer the tenon gently to compress the grain and test the fit in the seats.

logs.title: Seat Shaping
logs.description: Use a large chamfer bit to set a baseline on the top of the seat. Using an aggressive sander with 40 grit, carve the profile into a smooth curve by adding facets until it is mostly round. Smooth the profile with a foam interface pad and 80 grit sandpaper.

logs.title: Stretcher Joinery
logs.description: Use an elastic band across the legs & a ruler to mark and drill the 5/8" stretcher holes. Measure the internal dimension using two sticks, then cut the main stretcher to length. Then cut both ends of the stretcher to the round tenon shape. Repeat the process for the secondary stretcher.

logs.title: Leg & Stretcher Smoothing
logs.description: Use sandpaper and rasps to even out the tenon transitions and sand down the legs and stretchers to a smooth finish.

logs.title: Seat Divets
logs.description: Mark up where the polka dot divets should be placed and their rough size. Using a ball gouge, cut the divets into the seat. Using sandpaper, smooth out the bottoms of the divets and make their edge even.
